sentence: In this section, we describe the case study, its context, main objectives, and a summary of the envisaged technology that will be used to implement it.
In this section, we describe the case study, its context, main objectives, and a summary of the envisaged technology that will be used to implement it.
Context

It has given a big boost to the video calling applications like Zoom (Patnaik, 2020), doubled the usual usage level of voice and video calls on WhatsApp and Facebook Messenger (Iyengar, 2020), and not surprisingly, raised the usage of traditional social media sites such as Twitter, as people look for ways to stay updated with the latest outbreak news and keep in touch with friends and family (Koeze & Popper, 2020).

Although all of these applications bring lots of benefits to users during the pandemic, it is expected that this new online life will increase privacy risks for individuals mostly because of increased opportunity for privacy violation (Blose et al., 2020).

Although all of these applications bring lots of benefits to users during the pandemic, it is expected that this new online life will increase privacy risks for individuals mostly because of increased opportunity for privacy violation (Blose et al., 2020).

Although all of these applications bring lots of benefits to users during the pandemic, it is expected that this new online life will increase privacy risks for individuals mostly because of increased opportunity for privacy violation (Blose et al., 2020).
The unprecedented COVID-19 pandemic and the rise of social distancing affected the way we use the internet.

Personal data disclosure, in general,  poses serious threats to users privacy, leaving them to be victims of identity theft or cyber fraud (Hasan et al, 2013), discrimination in job searches, credit, and visa applications (McGregor et al, 2018), harassment and bullying (Pennebaker et al, 2007), and even long term, unknown impacts of these disclosures.

Other negative consequences such as stigma, discrimination, and prejudice are also reported as users’ main concerns especially when highly sensitive diseases such as mental disease, sexually transmitted disease, or physical disabilities are involved (Anderson & Agarwal, 2011; Obermeyer et al, 2011).
Talking specifically of the context of health, disclosing health data is considered particularly sensitive and might have significant consequences.
Talking specifically of the context of health, disclosing health data is considered particularly sensitive and might have significant consequences.
Many others started talking about their medical health history (e.g., I'm immunocompromised and my life counts!
All of these cases are considered as sensitive health data disclosure and might leave users exposed to victimization and privacy violation.
During the coronavirus pandemic, many online social networks (OSNs) users started disclosing their health data, for example, writing about their symptoms during the time they had coronavirus disease.
Objective

In the context described above, we aim to develop a machine-learning based approach that can automatically analyze tweets in the covid-19 atmosphere and decide if they are subject to physical health data disclosure or not.

DPVCG is a W3C community group started in 2018, with the main goal of providing a set of vocabulary in the context of privacy for describing personal data, purposes classification, and categories of data processing.

In this use-case, we use a subset of the vocabularies provided by the Data Privacy Vocabularies and Controls Community Group (DPVCG) (Pandit et al., 2019) to categorize different kinds of health data.

DPVCG is a W3C community group started in 2018, with the main goal of providing a set of vocabulary in the context of privacy for describing personal data, purposes classification, and categories of data processing.

The terms suggested by DPV under the category of MedicalHealth are Physical and mental health, drug test results, disabilities, health history (family or individual), health records, blood type, DNA code, and prescriptions.

Detection of health data in textual documents is a binary classification problem, e.g., having two classes of “health sensitive” and “non-health sensitive”, a model puts the sentence “I have a terrible flu” into the “health-sensitive” class, and the sentence “I’m sick of social distancing!” into the “non-health sensitive” class.

Categorization of personal data in textual documents, on the other hand, is performed when we have a set of categories of health data and want to associate a piece of text with one or more of these categories.

In this use-case, we use a subset of the vocabularies provided by the Data Privacy Vocabularies and Controls Community Group (DPVCG) (Pandit et al., 2019) to categorize different kinds of health data.

DPVCG is a W3C community group started in 2018, with the main goal of providing a set of vocabulary in the context of privacy for describing personal data, purposes classification, and categories of data processing.

DPVCG is a W3C community group started in 2018, with the main goal of providing a set of vocabulary in the context of privacy for describing personal data, purposes classification, and categories of data processing.

The terms suggested by DPV under the category of MedicalHealth are Physical and mental health, drug test results, disabilities, health history (family or individual), health records, blood type, DNA code, and prescriptions.
In this work, we just use family health history and individual health history labels to classify health-sensitive tweets.
Technology
In this section, we first describe the criteria for data collection and annotation in the COVID-19 corpus.
Data Collection
So, the ready COVID-19 tweets datasets have been reused after applying some filters to extract data suitable to our case study.
We first use a combination of our words/terms, and the suggested ones in (Sarker et al., 2020) to detect related tweets to coronavirus test results.
Words such as positive, negative, test, tests, tested with at least 1 of the pronouns I, she, he, we, they, my, her, his, their, our are also used to retrieve relevant tweets in this step.

We use the common symptoms of the disease, reported in World Health Organizations (WHO) guidelines, clinical settings, and self-reported symptoms on Twitter by  infected users  (Sarker et al., 2020) to filter tweets; symptoms such as cough, headache, mildfever, difficultybreathing, sneeze etc.

We use the common symptoms of the disease, reported in World Health Organizations (WHO) guidelines, clinical settings, and self-reported symptoms on Twitter by  infected users  (Sarker et al., 2020) to filter tweets; symptoms such as cough, headache, mildfever, difficultybreathing, sneeze etc.
A set of high risk diseases for COVID-19 are also used.

To this end, keywords and phrases such as family, mother, father, sister, brother, sibling, children, son, daughter, uncle, aunt, grandmother, grandfather, health history, medical history, disease history, family history, and names of diseases such as diabetes, heart and lung disease, and immunocompromised, are used as keywords to filter tweets.
Data Labeling
After collecting data, we adopt a manual annotation mechanism to tag tweets.
Furthermore, they tag the “health sensitive” data with individual health history or family health history.
Note that if a tweet contains a health data about a person other than users or their family members, it falls under the “non-health sensitive data” category (e.g.

Certain steps are usually considered before using textual raw data in the training phase.
First, as tweets usually come with lots of noise and uninformative strings such as HTML tags and advertisements, data cleaning is done to prepare data for classification.
First, as tweets usually come with lots of noise and uninformative strings such as HTML tags and advertisements, data cleaning is done to prepare data for classification.
Then, in the pre-processing phase, some tasks such as tokenization, stop word removal, and stemming are done.

Stemming, which is a key step to match the similar words in a texts, is the process of reducing a word to its stem by removing for example, its suffixes and prefixes, or by replacing it by the word root known as a lemma.

Whenever sensitive or personal data is involved, privacy concerns exist as well (Krishnamurthy & Wills, 2009).
One can imagine various scenarios in which the privacy of individuals’ sensitive data is threatened.

Moreover, In recent years, hundreds of data privacy scandals have been revealed; the 2018 Cambridge Analytica, for instance, was the center of one of the most known cases affected personal data of more than 87 million Facebook users.
With the increasing number of internet users, the amount of data that freely flows over the internet raises every second.
Simultaneously, the amount of data, of which many are sensitive or personal, collected by different organizations is growing rapidly.
Today, for example, many official organizations and companies keep digital documents containing different kinds of sensitive data (Abril et al., 2011).
One can imagine various scenarios in which the privacy of individuals’ sensitive data is threatened.

For example, many of the collected documents by companies are feasible to be copied by unauthorized parties, some resources containing personal data are needed to be made public every day (McCallister et al., 2010), and, many research activities in different areas such as health domain, need to have access to large sets of individual records to be successful.

GDPR, which went into effect on May 28, 2018, aims to protect data privacy of all the European Union citizens where-ever their data is targeted by organizations, regardless of their locations.
GDPR, which went into effect on May 28, 2018, aims to protect data privacy of all the European Union citizens where-ever their data is targeted by organizations, regardless of their locations.
This is where the EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) (REGULATION, 2016) plays its fundamental role.
GDPR, which went into effect on May 28, 2018, aims to protect data privacy of all the European Union citizens where-ever their data is targeted by organizations, regardless of their locations.
GDPR, which went into effect on May 28, 2018, aims to protect data privacy of all the European Union citizens where-ever their data is targeted by organizations, regardless of their locations.
GDPR imposes strict regulations on companies and organizations (data controllers) for collecting, processing, and storing individuals’ data.
GDPR imposes strict regulations on companies and organizations (data controllers) for collecting, processing, and storing individuals’ data.
This adverse consequence means that GDPR is an indispensable requirement for companies to be complied with.
As a result, it is of paramount importance for companies to redact, sanitize, or de-identify documents before storing, sharing, or disclosing information.

While in the past most of the data collected by companies had a structured format (e.g., database tables), the wide variety of data sources today are semi-structured and structured (e.g., plain text).

While in the past most of the data collected by companies had a structured format (e.g., database tables), the wide variety of data sources today are semi-structured and structured (e.g., plain text).
Grimes (2005) claimed that almost 80% of business and medical data are stored in unstructured formats.
Identifiers are the personally identifying information such as social security number which can disclose individuals identity.
Comparing to structured data, analyzing and understanding unstructured data to extract sensitive and personal information, is more challenging.
Comparing to structured data, analyzing and understanding unstructured data to extract sensitive and personal information, is more challenging.

Although the European General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) uses the term personal data to refer to information that links to individuals identity, other phrases are also used in different documents and works; e.g.
Article 4 (1) of the GDPR, defines personal data as:

“any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person (‘data subject’); an identifiable natural person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identifier such as a name, an identification number, location data, an online identifier or to one or more factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that natural person.”

“any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person (‘data subject’); an identifiable natural person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identifier such as a name, an identification number, location data, an online identifier or to one or more factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that natural person.”

“any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person (‘data subject’); an identifiable natural person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identifier such as a name, an identification number, location data, an online identifier or to one or more factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that natural person.”

“any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person (‘data subject’); an identifiable natural person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identifier such as a name, an identification number, location data, an online identifier or to one or more factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that natural person.”

“any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person (‘data subject’); an identifiable natural person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identifier such as a name, an identification number, location data, an online identifier or to one or more factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that natural person.”
Name, identification number, location, biometric data (GDPR, Recital 34), health data (GDPR, Recital 35), and even online identifiers are all mentioned as personal data in the Regulation.
Name, identification number, location, biometric data (GDPR, Recital 34), health data (GDPR, Recital 35), and even online identifiers are all mentioned as personal data in the Regulation.
Name, identification number, location, biometric data (GDPR, Recital 34), health data (GDPR, Recital 35), and even online identifiers are all mentioned as personal data in the Regulation.
Moreover, because of the fast advances of technology, many information that fell into the non-PII or non-personal data category in the past are considered PII or personal data today.
For example, an internet protocol (IP) address, a media access control (MAC) address, login Ids, or social media posts all could be used for the identification of a person.
Even cookies or radio frequency identification (RFID) tags are mentioned as PII in Recital 30, as they can be used by companies to identify users (Koch, n.d.).
It is also suggested by the European Court of Justice to include less explicit and subjective information such as individuals’ opinion, judgment, or work times and breaks, as personal data.
It is also suggested by the European Court of Justice to include less explicit and subjective information such as individuals’ opinion, judgment, or work times and breaks, as personal data.

The reason behind regulating differently special categories of data is that their misuse and revelation could cause more considerable harm and lead to more serious consequences on individuals fundamental rights.

The regulation also explicitly formulates some special categories of personal data (sensitive data) under Article 9 which their processing should be prohibited unless under some special circumstances and limited purposes defined in the article.

To determine whether a piece of information is personal data or not under the GDPR, Recital 26 emphasizes on the consideration of “all the means reasonably likely to be used” (based on the required time and costs, available technologies and technological development) to associate the information with a natural person, and hence, identification.

This assessment follow a risk-based approach: where there is a reasonable risk to associate information to an individual, it should be treated as personal data.
This assessment follow a risk-based approach: where there is a reasonable risk to associate information to an individual, it should be treated as personal data.

GDPR points two ways for data controllers to deal with personal data: First, to obtain data subjects’ consent for handling their personal data for a certain purpose, and second, to anonymize personal data in such a way that subjected natural person is not identifiable anymore.

GDPR points two ways for data controllers to deal with personal data: First, to obtain data subjects’ consent for handling their personal data for a certain purpose, and second, to anonymize personal data in such a way that subjected natural person is not identifiable anymore.

GDPR points two ways for data controllers to deal with personal data: First, to obtain data subjects’ consent for handling their personal data for a certain purpose, and second, to anonymize personal data in such a way that subjected natural person is not identifiable anymore.

As the first legal solution is not always applicable, anonymization is required in different cases; the process in which the first step is the detection of personal or sensitive data which might be used to identify data subjects.
Although it is believed that personal data is the European equivalent of PII, They are not exactly the same, as personal data includes a wider range of information .
PII is a term regularly used in North America and often referenced by US government agencies such as the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) .
In Europe, however, the term personal data is more recognized as it has been defined and mentioned in many articles of the GDPR.
The sensitivity of PII is one of the key factors in determining an individual perception of privacy (Lederer, 2003).

Department of Defense (DOD) of United States, for example, defines sensitive data as information that if lost or misused, has significant risk or could cause harm in a more serious way to individuals in comparison to the other kinds of personal data (“DOD Privacy Program, 2014”).
As it is represented, PII is a subset of PI; which means not all the PIs gives the ability to disclose someone’s identity.

In data protection law, on the other hand, the notion of sensitivity indicates that further and stricter control mechanisms should be considered for the processing of sensitive data compared to other PIIs (Bygrave, 2002).

Bing (1972), for example, suggests to assign some level of sensitivity to PIIs, from the most sensitive to the least sensitive, based on these criteria: 1) inherently sensitive information such as sexual or medical data.
2) judgmental data that its disclosure could cause harm or threaten the data subject, and 3) biographical data that gives information about more sensitive data.
2) judgmental data that its disclosure could cause harm or threaten the data subject, and 3) biographical data that gives information about more sensitive data.

However, one can realize that with the huge amount of data produced every day, manual sanitization is a costly and time-consuming solution (Dorr et al., 2006).
The term Named Entity, which was first introduced in the sixth Message Understanding Conference (MUC-6) is applied to any real or abstract concept denotable by a name.
Named Entity Recognition (NER), thus, refers to the detection of named entities in unstructured data such as textual documents (Nadeau & Sekine, 2007).
Named Entity Recognition (NER), thus, refers to the detection of named entities in unstructured data such as textual documents (Nadeau & Sekine, 2007).
NER is an essential sub-task of various Natural Language Processing (NLP) systems such as Information Extraction (IE), question answering, Relation Extraction(RE), etc.
It has also been used in the context of document sanitization to ease the burden of manual search through documents.
Early NER systems leveraged a handcrafted rule-based approach, in which for different pieces of information, certain patterns were identified and adopted for searching.

There are some other works in health domain (Douglass et al., 2005; Tveit et al., 2004), which focused on deleting sensitive data in medical records based on Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) (Act, A.
(1996)) “Safe Harbor” guideline, which specifies 18 certain patterns of data (e.g.
names, medical record numbers, biometric features, full-face photographs, etc.)
If trained well with an adequate number of training data, NER models achieve high precision, usually above 80% (Hassan et al., 2019).
Subsequently, the rule-based NER approaches were later replaced by machine-learning-based techniques.
If trained well with an adequate number of training data, NER models achieve high precision, usually above 80% (Hassan et al., 2019).
(2018) proposed an approach based on NER, IOB2 named entity tagger (Sang & Veenstra, 1999), and conditional random fields (CRFs) to anonymize unstructured data.
(2018) proposed an approach based on NER, IOB2 named entity tagger (Sang & Veenstra, 1999), and conditional random fields (CRFs) to anonymize unstructured data.

The main idea in this work is to define three categories of personal data: identifiers such as passport number, quasi-identifier such as location, age, postal code, and confidential information such as disease names.

Although not proposing a concrete system, the work in (Abril et al., 2011) represents a method with two main characteristics: first, they showed by an experiment on an annotated Spanish dataset called CoNLL02 (Jia Deng et al., 2009), that it is acceptable to consider Named Entities detected by NERC systems and Private Entities (PE) detected by humans, almost coincident.
Thus, it is possible to base the Private Entity detection  systems on top of the various available NERC methods.

This approach maintain some level of semantic information and does not severely hamper the utility; b) Entity swapping: in this approach similar entities of the documents from a same set, or entities  within the same document can be swapped; and c) Entity noise addition: in this approach entities are replaced by some semantic noise.
That is, instead of swapping similar entities, a private entity can be replaced by another private entity from another repository, which does not exist in the document.
That is, instead of swapping similar entities, a private entity can be replaced by another private entity from another repository, which does not exist in the document.
The authors also provides a mechanism to set a balance between privacy preserving and document utility, which is the information intended to be revealed, by formalizing the “K-safety” notion.
The regular form of NEs is not the only feature used to extract sensitive data.

In another work, for example, instead of using patterns, Chakaravarthy et al (2008) proposed a framework called ERASE, which works based on a database of entities (e.g., persons, diseases, organizations, etc.)
modeling public knowledge, and detect sensitive data.
Each entity is associated with some terms representing the context of the entity (e.g., name, date of birth, home address, etc.
for the entity person).
This framework supports dynamic sanitization based on the authorization status of a reader requesting access to the document.
This framework supports dynamic sanitization based on the authorization status of a reader requesting access to the document.

It also provides a sanitization method to automatically remove the minimum number of context terms associated with sensitive entities, in a way that inferring the sensitive entities from the remaining context terms, and thus disclosure, would be impossible.

It also provides a sanitization method to automatically remove the minimum number of context terms associated with sensitive entities, in a way that inferring the sensitive entities from the remaining context terms, and thus disclosure, would be impossible.

It also provides a sanitization method to automatically remove the minimum number of context terms associated with sensitive entities, in a way that inferring the sensitive entities from the remaining context terms, and thus disclosure, would be impossible.
This method prevents the consequence of removing all the named entities in documents and leaving them with no useful information, that might be happened in the NER/pattern-based approaches.
K-safety in ERASE is inspired by the “K-anonymity” proposed by Sweeney (2002) for structured data anonymization.
K-safety in ERASE is inspired by the “K-anonymity” proposed by Sweeney (2002) for structured data anonymization.

K-safety requires, for each sensitive entity e, there are at least K other sensitive entities that contain maximum number of e’s context terms in a document, so an adversary could not associate the context terms with a specific sensitive term, here e. However, the authors state that in this method a set of homogeneous documents is required and gaining a K-safety sanitized document is a NP-hard problem.

Some other techniques use dictionaries to form the privacy context of different domains.
(2011) constructed a privacy dictionary and proposed an approach for the automated content analysis of privacy on textual documents.
(2011) constructed a privacy dictionary and proposed an approach for the automated content analysis of privacy on textual documents.
This privacy dictionary includes eight categories for privacy-sensitive context including  Law, OpenVisible, OutcomeState, NormsRequisites, Restriction, NegativePrivacy, Intimacy, and PrivateSecret.

To automatically analyze a text in terms of privacy-related information, the appearance of each dictionary term in the text is counted and the score of the relevant category or context to which the word belongs is incremented.
The proposed privacy dictionary can also be used with the existing automated content-analysis software such as LIWC (LIWC software: Pennebaker et al., 2007).

This task is repeated for all the words in a text and finally, a matrix will be obtained for each document (row), representing the context values for each category (columns).

While the above-mentioned works focus on the detection of privacy-related keywords using NE patterns, databases of entities, and dictionaries, some other adopted more comprehensive, semantical approaches.
In their work, they criticized the general assumptions behind the NER-base methods that every named entity is sensitive information and should be considered as sensitive data.

Instead, they associate the notion of sensitive data with the amount of information each data provides: if a term provides too much information (based on a threshold) then it is sensitive data and should be anonymized.

Considering the domain knowledge, K, and a set of sensitive data, C, D^'is a C-sanitization version of document D, if it does not contain any term t or sets of terms T which individually or in combination can be used to disclose any sensitive entity in C. To assess if entities in C are disclosed by any terms in T, semantic relatedness between them is calculated.
A higher value of PMI means a higher disclosure risk.

To do so, a g(C) parameter is added to the model, which is a set of generalized words, specifying the maximum level of semantic disclosure for each sensitive entity c in C. For example, applying an (AIDS, chronic disorder)-sanitization over a document means that, using the protected document, it is only possible to reveal the amount of information of AIDS that is, at most, correspondent to its generalization, chronic disease.
The authors emphasized that their proposed method, for the first time, exploit co-occurrence of the words for detection of sensitive inferences in textual data to support privacy.

In another work presented by Hassan et al (2019), the authors suggested a method based on a neural network version of the word embedding model (Mikolov et al., 2013) to determine the degree of association between a want-to-be protected entity and a term in a document.

If the calculated similarity between an entity to be protected and a phrase/word is more than a threshold value, then the phrase/word will be considered as sensitive data, thus must be removed or masked.
PrivacyBot (Tesfay et al., 2019) is another tool developed to detect privacy sensitive information in unstructured texts (English Tweets from Twitter) using Random Forest (RF) classifier.

In another work, presented in (Imran-Daud et al., 2016), personal data identification and categorization are leveraged as a tool for implementing a fine-grained, privacy-preserving access control mechanism for social networks.

For example, a user can enforce different access control rules for the representation of contents in the medical health domain to different readers: for readers from the group family friend the maximum level of disclosing health-related information is Hepatitis, whereas, this level for strangers is disease.

Amazon Macie is a service supporting data security and privacy of data by discovering and protecting sensitive data stored in Amazon Web Services (AWS).
Additionally, it can measure data privacy risks based on models such as k-anonymity and l-diversity to give an insight of the re-identification risks for different identifiers and quasi-identifiers.
Some technical tools and solutions are also available for performing automatic detection of sensitive data in textual resources.
SpaCy (SpaCy: Named entity recognition, 2018) and Stanford NER (Manning et al., 2014), for example, perform some NER tasks.
In 2016, another text anonymizer tool (United Kingdom Data Service, n.d.) was proposed by the United Kingdom Data Archive (UKDA).

IBM PII Annotator (PII Annotator, n.d.) is another tool which can extract PIIs such as national identification number, phone number, postal code, credit card data, name of countries, etc.
There are also some software packages based on machine-learning and statistical NER approaches, including Amazon Macie (Amazon Macie, n.d.) and Google’s Cloud DLP (Cloud Data Loss Prevention, n,d.).

Similarly, Cloud DLP leverages machine-learning techniques to scan, classify, and mask sensitive data.
Additionally, it can measure data privacy risks based on models such as k-anonymity and l-diversity to give an insight of the re-identification risks for different identifiers and quasi-identifiers.
Each group of the mentioned solutions in the previous section has their own strength and weakness points.
It is crucial to highlight the advantages and disadvantages of the previous research works on textual data de-identification to assist the research community select the best methods for their works.
First, not all of the NEs refer to sensitive data.
Hence, NERs might not be able to cover words or combination of words which have not appeared in training sets or NE dictionaries (e.g., rare diseases).

Most NER-based approaches fail in detecting various information related to separate entities and instead make an implicit assumption that the whole document points to one single entity (Hassan et al., 2019), which is not always correct.
Preserving document utility is ignored during data masking in most of the NER-based solutions.
In exploiting supervised techniques for sensitive data detection (e.g.

(Caliskan Islam et al., 2014), (Hassan et al., 2019),(Mehdy, N., Kennington, C., & Mehrpouyan, 2019), and(Mehdy, N., Kennington, C., & Mehrpouyan, 2019)), one of the weaknesses regards the use of training datasets: if a sensitive word does not appear in the dataset used to train a model, the model is not able to identify it later.
Specifically, because these models use the Web as the corpus, the possibility of discarding a term in them is near zero.
Advantages of previous research on textual data de-identification.
